Empires & Puzzles Costumed Griffex Review: The Modern Mana Master

The beard is bigger, the stats are beefier, and the mana drain is deadlier. Costumed Griffex has arrived to silence the haters. Find out why this mana manipulator is finally the wizard we were promised.
Costumed Griffex Review: He's Back, He's Buff, and He's Taking Your Mana
Costumed Griffex: The Glow-Up We Didn't Know We Needed
When Griffex was first released, he was the butt of many jokes. "Too slow," they said. "No damage," they laughed. Well, who's laughing now?
(released August 2025) has stormed onto the scene with a vengeance. He retains his unique "Mana Manipulator" identity but backs it up with
and a class change that makes him significantly more annoying to deal with. This review focuses on his
, the only version you should be using if you want to win.

The costume art is a direct upgrade. The purple is more vibrant, the beard is even more majestic (if that was possible), and he now wields a strange, futuristic-looking camera device alongside his magical aura. Is he taking a picture of your defeat? Possibly. The "Modifier of Obscura" title fits perfectly with his new, darker, and more mysterious vibe. It’s a great evolution that keeps the core theme but makes it feel fresh and powerful.
This is where the magic happens.
This puts him right in the mix with current top-tier heroes.
. With Limit Break 2, he pushes over
. He is a tanky beast who can survive the initial onslaught of Fast snipers, ensuring he lives long enough to fire his skill.
Solid and reliable. Combined with his HP, he is a wall.
Compared to his base version (which had ~1697 HP), this is a completely different hero. He is no longer a liability on your team; he is an anchor.
The skill remains functionally similar to the base but with key improvements:
Still reduces Holy enemies' mana by
. This remains one of the strongest counters to Yellow heroes in the game.
The drain on non-Holy enemies is bumped to
(from 50%). While 5% seems small, every bit counts when trying to prevent a enemy special.
Still grants +30% mana to Dark allies and +15% to others.
(This has no effect on other Griffex characters.)
This prevents the cheese strategy of running multiple Griffexes to infinitely loop mana. Fair play, SG.
This is huge. It makes it much easier to drop his tile count. With a Level 29 Magic troop and the 5% costume bonus, he is much more responsive.
With 3000+ HP (LB2) and Monk withstand chance (30%), his effective health is arguably one of the highest in the game for a support hero.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Super Elemental family bonus shines even brighter with modern stats.
Generating Power Gems is great, but now that Griffex can actually survive, he will generate
of them over the course of a battle. A surviving Griffex means a board full of ticking time bombs for the enemy.
The costume boosts the extra elemental damage to
. His tile damage against Holy enemies is catastrophic. He can practically kill a yellow tank with 3 tiles.
damage from Holy troops/skills (up from -10%). This makes him incredibly tanky against yellow stacks. He is the ultimate anti-yellow shield.
further cements his role as a tank/support. Combined with his passive resistance to Holy, he becomes extremely difficult to kill with tile damage alone.
Base Griffex was a joke. Costumed Griffex is the punchline—and he's punching back.
The costume stats effectively "de-creep" him, bringing him right up to the level of late 2025 heroes. While his skill is still Slow, his durability ensures he is relevant.
He is a staple for Rush Attack wars and a very strong pick for attacking yellow-heavy defenses. He is no longer just a niche pick; he is a viable main-deck hero for many players.
The Difference is Night and Day.
There is no contest. The Costume has ~800 more HP, ~300 more Defense, and significantly better passives.
is a massive upgrade over Druid for him. The chance to
(like Mana Stop, Silence, or Mindless Attack) is critical for a Slow hero. If he resists a silence and fires, he flips the entire battle.
Never use the base version if you have the costume. The costume is the hero.
He needs to live. His job is to cast
. With 3000+ HP, boosting his defense makes that HP pool worth even more.
You sacrifice some of that sweet +150% tile damage potential.
Leans into his +150% elemental damage passive. A 3-match of purple tiles into a yellow hero effectively deletes them.
Slightly less bulk, but Monk class helps him survive ailments.
. His value comes from firing his special, not just tile damage.
Between the massive stat boost, Damage Reduction passive (-25%), and Aether Power, he is very hard to kill.
-100% Mana to Holy and +150% Damage against them. He is the hard counter to the Holy meta.
The 30% resist chance can win games by shrugging off control effects.
Fueling your other Dark heroes is invaluable.
Even with the costume bonus, he is slow. Fast snipers can still potentially pick him off or control him before he fires.
If he is the last man standing, he cannot win the match (unless by tile damage).
He needs heavy hitters alongside him to capitalize on the mana swing.
He is a god here. Absolute S-Tier.
Specifically against Yellow tanks or heavy Yellow teams.
He can work as a Tank or Flank in Rush wars, or as a punishing Flank in standard wars against yellow stacks.
Combine Griffex's massive drain with other mana controllers to ensure the enemy never fires a single special.
In Rush, C. Griffex at tank is a nightmare. If he fires, the attacker is reset to zero, and your flanks charge up.
Toon heroes are annoying as they resist the mana cut.
A taunt hero can absorb the drain (though Holy taunters still get drained 100%).
Running a full team of Slow heroes is risky. Pair him with Average/Fast heroes to bridge the gap until he fires.
If you get this costume, level it immediately. The stats alone make him a carry for map stages and early raids. Put him in your center position and watch him soak up damage.

You might have benched the original Griffex, but it's time to dust him off. The Costumed version is a legitimate contender. He is worth the Limit Breaks, especially for Rush wars and as a counter to the prevalent Holy tanks. The Monk class alone makes him infinitely more playable than the Druid version.
Even with the costume, some were wary:
"I expect his second skill to be changed... SG generally doesn’t like any combo that allows you to loop specials."
(And they were right, the loop was removed).
"This is an awkward reply... On an attack team against a Gooric tank... a mana drain for enemies and mana boost for slow... could make sense."
- A player realizing his potential on offense.
"He is a beast on attack in VF tournys. Don’t underestimate him."
Costumed Griffex is the ultimate redemption arc. He went from zero to hero (literally). He is a specialized tool, yes, but he is the

tool for his specific job: shutting down Holy heroes and fueling the Dark engine. If you enjoy controlling the board and denying your opponent the satisfaction of using their skills, Costumed Griffex is your new best friend.
A must-have for Rush Attack and a top-tier counter-pick for War Offense. The beard is finally feared.
